text: hi I'm Louise story I read about Wall
Street for the New York Times I'm joined
by my colleague Eric - who also writes
on Wall Street
it's report card time for the nation's
largest banks and just like students at
the end of the quarter the banks and
investors themselves are sort of getting
jittery about the results some of the
results have come out already because
the information was relate to the banks
on Tuesday I think this is actually
pretty good news from the public's
perspective because we're seeing at the
largest banks there may not be much more
taxpayer money needed you know the
government already gave so much money to
these banks the government already gave
forty five billion to Bank of America
for example and it turned out the Bank
of America only needs thirty four
billion dollars of that money and Bank
of America might not use the government
money for the 34 so I think we may see
some the taxpayer money getting returned
right well even though taxpayer money
may not be additional taxpayer money may
not be required I think you also have to
look at it from the investor point of
view and that is you know how much more
money is going to be needed or converted
into common stock from the government's
initial investment of preferred stock
and that means for the average investor
they could see their shares diluted but
the other thing that's sort of happening
simultaneously is that investors may
have already priced some of this in so
it's Paul so possible the bank stocks
may rally so we really don't know what's
going to happen you know this reminds me
of in 1933 when FDR came in and shut
down most of the banks in the country he
closed some and then the ones he
reopened he said these are healthy and
that's very much what the Obama
administration is trying to do they're
trying to say we've sussed out the
problems we've given the capital that
they need and now the banking system is
okay and what will be interesting is
whether that convinces investors or not
on Thursday when the government releases
its findings on the banks will that
bring confidence back to the banking
system and I know that's certainly what
regulators are hoping for right and I
think the answer is we don't know until
the results will get really
